# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code to solve your problem:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

# Testing the function
dt = now() # get current time
bumped_time = timezone_bumper(dt)
println("Bumped time: ", bumed_time)
```
This function works by adding a number of hours to the provided DateTime object. By default, it adds 3 hours but this can be changed when calling the function. If you try to pass a Date type instead of a DateTime, Julia will throw an error because Date and DateTime are different types in Julia's Dates module.
